results.title: Jenny
results.brief_description:
Jenny, the manager of a nightclub of dubious reputation, gets involved with Lucien, a member of a gang of criminals. Benoit, the crooked owner of the club, employs a hunchback accomplice to help put an end to their affair. Meanwhile, Jenny’s daughter falls in love with Lucien and becomes her mother’s rival. ‘Jenny’ is Marcel Carne’s first film as director and the first of seven collaborations with screenwriter Jacques Prevert. Reference: Bloomsbury Foreign Film Guide.

Credits: Director, Marcel Carne ; writers, Jacques Prevert, Pierre Rocher, Jacques Constant ; photography, Jean Stelli ; music, Joseph Kosma, Lionel Cazaux ; art direction, Jean d’Eaubonne.
Cast: Francoise Rosay, Albert Prejean, Charles Vanel, Lisette Lanvin, Jean-Louis Barrault, Robert Le Vigan, Roland Toutain, Sylvia Bataille, Margo Lion, Rene Genin.

results.title: Rendez-Vous a Bray = Meeting in Bray
results.brief_description:
Of Luxembourg nationality, Julien is not drafted for the First World War, and is therefore able to continue his piano lessons in Paris. His friend Jacques is a pilot doing service at the war front. One day, Julien receives a telegram in which Jacques invites him for a stay at his remote estate in Bray. Julien leaves to meet his friend, but Jacques does not show up. His only company at the lovely estate is a reticent woman whom, he assumes to be the housekeeper. By the time Julien decides to return to Paris, persuaded his friend has died in the war, he reads in the newspaper that the weather may have been the cause of Jacques’absence. Reference: Flanders International Film Festival (Ghent). http://www.surf-inn.be/Archieven/filmfestival/eng/program/filmlist/PBP/rendezvousbray.htm

Credits: Director, writer, Andre Delvaux ; photography, Ghislain Cloquet.
Cast: Bulle Ogier, Roger van Hool, Boby Lapointe, Jean Bouise, Anna Karina, Mathiey Carriere.

results.title: Chouans! (Cinemascope Print)
results.creator_credit: Philippe De Broca and Ariel Zeitoun
results.brief_description:
Aristocrat, philosopher and inventor, Count Savinien de Kerfadec loses his wife as she gives birth to their daughter, Celine. The same night he brings home Aurele, a newborn he found of the doorstep of the church. A few years later, young Tarquin who is on his way to the seminar, runs away and becomes the third addition to the eccentric Kerfadec household. As the children grow up, a love triangle develops, until the day the boys are sent away to make their way in the world. In 1793, Tarquin comes back to Brittany as a representant of the Republic, in charge of repressing the uprising in the Western provinces and possibly woe Celine. But Aurele and Celine, whose love for each other has blossomed, are active among those called ‘Les Chouans’.

Credits: Producer, Ariel Zeitoun ; director, Philippe de Broca ; writers, Daniel Boulanger, Philippe de Brocca, Jerome Tonnerre ; photography, Bernard Zitzermann ; music, Georges Delerue.
Cast: Sopphie Marceau, Lambert Wilson, Philippe Noiret, Stephane Freiss, Jean-Pierre Cassel, Roger Dumas.

results.title: Germinal
results.brief_description:
Etienne is a young man who seeks work in the coal mines of the North of France. After experiencing the harsh working conditions of the mine, he becomes a labor activist and tries to organize a strike to improve wages and conditions. Etienne is also tormented by the mine owner, whose promiscuous wife steps out on him at will. Etienne falls in love with the daughter of a fellow miner. Her loyalty to her father and the fear he might lose his job makes her initially unresponsive to Etienne’s romantic advances.

Credits: Producer, Eugene Tuchere ; director, Yves Allegret ; writer, Charles Spaak ; photography, Jean Bourgoin ; music, Michel Magne ; art direction, Lucien Aguettand.
Cast: Jean Sorel, Berthe Grandval, Lea Padovani, Claude Brasseur, Bernard Blier.

results.title: Tintin et les Oranges Bleues
results.brief_description:
Professor Zalamea, a Spanish scientist, sends to Prof. Tournesol a blue orange with mysterious properties. But the orange is stolen soon after. Tintin, Captain Haddock and Snowy set off in hot pursuit

Credits: Director, Philippe Condroyer ; writer, Andre Barret ; photography, Jean Badal ; music, Antoine Duhamel.
Cast: Jean-Pierre Talbot, Jean Bouise, Jenny Orleans, Felix Fernandez, Max Elloy.

results.title: Escapade
results.brief_description:
Agnes receives a phone call in which a man named Philippe gives her a rendez-vous. Thinking it is Philippe, her fiance, with whom she just had a fight who want to kiss and make-up, Agnes decides to meet him, even though she is grounded. When she arrives at the meeting place, she is welcomed by gangsters who ask her to mellow Frank, a gangster who double-crossed them.

Credits: Producer, Christine Gouze-Renal ; director, Ralph Habib ; writers, Albert Valentin, Marcel Achard ; photography, Pierre Petit ; music, Michel Emer ; art direction, Georges Wakhevitch ; assitant directors, Claude Pinoteau, Alain Jessua.
Cast: Louis Jourdan, Dany Carrel, Roger Hanin, Margaret Hung, Jean Lec, Lise Delamare, Claude Genia.

results.title: Le Beau Serge = Handsome Serge
results.creator_credit: Claude Chabrol, Jean Cotet and Ajym Films
results.brief_description:
After 10 years away, Francois returns to the village where he grew up and meets up again with old friend Serge. Serge used to be the envy of all because of his intelligence and beauty, but he is now only a shadow of his former self. Married to Yvonne, Serge has become an alcoholic after the couple lost their child. Francois is willing to do anything to help his friend and the two protagonists indulge in a transfer of personal guilt, then an ‘exchange of redemption’. ‘Le beau Serge’ was the first film of French critic-turned-director Claude Chabrol and is widely acknowledged as the first film of the French New Wave. Though not a murder melodrama, the film is heavily influenced by the works of Chabrol’s idol Alfred Hitchcock, ‘Shadow of a Doubt’ in particular. Two of the principal actors - Jean-Claude Brialy and Gerard Blain - also appear in Chabrol’s follow-up film, ‘Les Cousins’. Also available on VHS.

Credits: Producer, Jean Cotet ; director, writer, Claude Chabrol ; photography, Henri Decae ; music, Emile Delpierre, Geo Legros ; assistant directors, Philippe de Broca, Claude de Givray, Claude Cerval.
Cast: Gerard Blain, Jean-Claude Brialy, Bernadette Lafont, Claude Chabrol, Philippe de Broca, Michele Meritz, Jeanne Perez, Edmond Beauchamps.

results.title: Vivement Dimanche! = Confidentially Yours!
results.brief_description:
Julien Vercel is a real-estate dealer accused of killing his wife and her lover. He hides in his office while his secretary Barbara sets out to discover what really happened and why. When Barbara starts looking into the dark past of her boss’s wife, she comes across illicit love affairs, a prostitution ring and shady private detectives. “I liked the idea of a ‘serie noire’ (detective novel) without gangsters. Second, the relationship between a secretary and her boss, which can be so amusing, has not been explored in recent films. And most of all, I wanted to make a detective film with Fanny Ardant. I read many novels by Williams and found that he created the best roles for women. I liked the idea of an ‘ordinary’ woman from daily life conducting the investigation. Fanny represents in France a certain elegance and lyricism. I wanted to show that she could be a comedienne - in a popular role, behind a typewriter.” Reference: Annette Insdorf. ‘Francois Truffaut’. Cambridge University Press, 1994.

Credits: Producer, Armand Barbault ; director, Francois Truffaut ; writers, Francois Truffaut, Suzanne Schiffman, Jean Aurel ; photography, Nestor Almendros ; music, Georges Delerue ; art direction, Hilton McConnico.
Cast: Fanny Ardant, Jean-Louis Trintignant, Philippe Laudenbach, Caroline Sihol, Philippe Morier-Genoud, Jean-Pierre Kalfon.

results.title: La Maison des Bories = the House of the Bories
results.brief_description:
Carl is the young scholar who comes to live with French geologist Julian and his wife Isabelle and two children. Carl is eager to study with the famous geologist, but soon he is involved in a love affair with his mentor’s wife.

Credits: Producer, Philippe Dussart ; director, Jacques Doniol-Valcroze ; writer, Anne Tromelin ; photography, Ghislain Cloquet.
Cast: Marie Dubois, Maurice Garrel, Helene Vallier, Mathieu Cariere, Veronique Maurin.

results.title: L'etrange Monsieur Victor = the Strange Mr. Victor
results.creator_credit: Jean Gremillon, Albert Valentin and Raoul Ploquin
results.brief_description:
A respectable businessman during the day, Monsieur Victor is also the boss of gang of thieves. When a blackmailer threatens to reveal the true nature of his business, Monsieur Victor kills him with a tool belonging to his neighbour, Bastien Robineau. Bastien is found guilty and condemned to seven years of hard labour. Seven years later, Bastien comes back to town to seek revenge. ‘Monsieur Victor’ was partially financed by the German company UFA. The exteriors were shot in Toulon (South of France) and the interiors at the Babelsberg studios in Berlin. The film had no success when released in 1938. Raoul Ploquin, the producer, took the initiative to re-issue the film in 1974, after lengthy research in various cinematheques. The film was then hailed as one of Gremillon’s finest work.

Credits: Producer, Raoul Ploquin, Albert Valentin ; director, Jean Gremillon ; writers, Marcel Achard, Charles Spaak ; photography, Werner Krien ; music, Roland Manuel.
Cast: Raimu, Madeleine Renaud, Pierre Blanchar, Marcelle Geniat, Andrex, Viviane Romance, Marcel Maupi.
